meaning: approval or praise.
state or assert to be the case.
given to sudden and unaccountable changes of mood or behaviour.
feeling or expressing remorse at the recognition that one has done wrong.
indicate the exact position of (a border or boundary).
describe or portray (something) precisely.
criticize unfairly; disparage.
a temporary departure from the main subject in speech or writing.
not candid or sincere, typically by pretending that one knows less about something than one really does.
conceal or disguise one's true feelings or beliefs.
deriving ideas, style, or taste from a broad and diverse range of sources.
the ability to produce a desired or intended result.
an urgent need or demand.
treating serious issues with deliberately inappropriate humour; flippant.
well chosen or suited to the circumstances.
prevent or obstruct (an anticipated event or action) by taking advance action.
not feeling or showing emotion.
unable to be appeased or placated.
just begun and so not fully formed or developed; rudimentary.
a state of extreme poverty; destitution.

accustom (someone) to something, especially something unpleasant.

a state of physical or mental weariness; lack of energy.
not telling the truth; lying.

remove (a need or difficulty).
assertive of authority in a domineering way, especially with regard to trivial matters.
harsh criticism or censure.
characterized by pretentious or showy display; designed to impress.

a felicitous phrase

his cold, impassive face
he was an implacable enemy of Ted's
